title: Spread (projective geometry)
summary: A frequently studied problem in discrete geometry is to identify ways in which an object can be covered by other simpler objects such as points, lines, and planes. In projective geometry, a specific instance of this problem that has numerous applications is determining whether, and how, a projective space can be covered by pairwise disjoint subspaces which have the same dimension; such a partition is called a spread. Specifically, a spread of a projective space P G ( d , K ) {\displaystyle PG(d,K)} , where d â‰¥ 1 {\displaystyle d\geq 1} is an integer and K {\displaystyle K} a division ring, is a set of r {\displaystyle r} -dimensional subspaces, for some 0 < r < d {\displaystyle 0<r<d} such that every point of the space lies in exactly one of the elements of the spread.
